urn:contentItem:5WNB-XRH1-JBJ7-N2R2-00000-00ASX on track to pass 70002019-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:09ZLexisNexisASX on track to pass 7000Luke Housego

The All Ordinaries topped its pre-GFC all-time high on Thursday, the S&P/ASX 200 is not far behind and experts say there's more to come.

Despite the benchmark S&P/ASX200 adding more than 20 per cent year to date and the All Ordinaries passing its pre-GFC all-time high on Thursday, experts expect the momentum will be sustained, taking the indices past 7000 points.

The previous 6853.6-point high for the All Ordinaries was set almost 12 years ago on November 1, 2007, but that was passed on Thursday. The ASX200 was close behind, finishing the week at 6793.4, just below the pre-GFC record of 6828 points record.

With further monetary easing expected in the US, Europe and domestically, the market is expected to continue its firm run in the short term.

"I'm still bullish on Aussie shares," Stanford Brown chief investment officer Ashley Owen said. "Seven thousand [points] is not far away. It's a hop, skip and a jump away so I can say that being reached quite easily."

The Australian market is inextricably linked to overseas events, Mr Owen explained, with the US economy particularly relevant to whether the local market rise will continue.

"Every single move is basically driven by what happens overseas," he said. "In the US you've got massive monetary stimulus. You've got very low rates and talks of cuts."

Reserve Bank of Australia governor Dr Philip Lowe said on Thursday that Australians should "expect an extended period of low interest rates", increasing expectations the bank would cut at least once more before the year was out.

"The RBA is encouraging people, economic participants - companies, individually investors, what have you - they want people to be able to put money into risky assets, whether it be investing in plant and equipment, or investing in equity markets," said Plato Investment Management managing director Don Hamson.

The low rate environment has resulted in share price growth that was not necessarily being linked to company performance, according to Dr Hamson.

"I don't see earnings being fantastic at the moment. That's why rates are where they are."

BetaShares chief economist David Bassanese expects the rise in Australian shares to continue but said growth would not be the driving force.

"I think what we're seeing is a bit of a build-up of equity markets that can really be sustained for the moment, because central banks are basically still focused on trying to get inflation," Mr Bassanese said. "But it's going to be more driven on the back of low interest rates than a solid rebound in growth.

"What we're essentially seeing is a repricing of the equity markets around the world, because of central bank easing."

Year-to-date gains for the benchmark index are now above 20 per cent, but there are risks that remain that will determine if the growth is sustained.

"I think the China thing is years and years away, trade is only part of the picture, it's more about strategy. It's more about power, it's more about military dominance," Stanford Brown's Mr Owen said.

He believed there was also a bigger risk on the horizon in the form of regulatory intervention.

"It's more the anti-trust movement against the big tech stocks, it's more of a medium-term concern," he said. "I think what will happen within five years is you'll see the big US tech stocks broken up."

The significance of the big tech companies to the US market means breaking them could have a broader destabilising impact.

Mr Owen was still optimistic despite those risks and with the 7000-point threshold now in sight, another key level is further away. Adjusted for inflation, the pre-GFC high for the S&P/ASX 200 is closer to 8800 points.

"The big target, which is the after-inflation target, it's another 27 per cent, which is a long way away," Mr Owen said.

Despite the benchmark S&P/ASX200 adding more than 20 per cent year to date and the All Ordinaries passing its pre-GFC all-time high on Thursday, experts expect the momentum to be sustained, taking the indices past 7000 points.

The previous 6853.6-point high for the All Ordinaries was set almost 12 years ago on November 1, 2007, but that was passed on Thursday. The ASX200 was close behind, finishing the week at 6793.4, just below the pre-GFC record of 6828 points.

With further monetary easing expected in the United States, Europe and domestically, the market is expected to continue its firm run in the short term.

"I'm still bullish on Aussie shares," Stanford Brown chief investment officer Ashley Owen said. "Seven thousand [points] is not far away. It's a hop, skip and a jump away so I can see that being reached quite easily."

The Australian market is inextricably linked to overseas events, Mr Owen explained, with the US economy particularly relevant to whether the local market rise will continue.

"Every single move is basically driven by what happens overseas," he said. "In the US you've got massive monetary stimulus. You've got very low rates and talks of cuts."

Reserve Bank of Australia governor Dr Philip Lowe said on Thursday that Australians should "expect an extended period of low interest rates", increasing expectations the bank would cut at least once more before the year was out.

"The RBA is encouraging people, economic participants - companies, individually investors, what have you - they want people to be able to put money into risky assets, whether it be investing in plant and equipment, or investing in equity markets," said Plato Investment Management managing director Don Hamson.

The low-rate environment has resulted in share price growth that was not necessarily being linked to company performance, said Dr Hamson.

"I don't see earnings being fantastic at the moment. That's why rates are where they are," he said.

BetaShares chief economist David Bassanese expects the rise in Australian shares to continue, but said growth would not be the driving force.

"I think what we're seeing is a bit of a build-up of equity markets that can really be sustained for the moment, because central banks are basically still focused on trying to get inflation," Mr Bassanese said. "But it's going to be more driven on the back of low interest rates than a solid rebound in growth.

"What we're essentially seeing is a re-pricing of the equity markets around the world, because of central bank easing."

Year-to-date gains for the benchmark index are now above 20 per cent, but there are risks that remain that will determine if the growth is sustained.

"I think the China thing is years and years away - trade is only part of the picture, it's more about strategy. It's more about power, it's more about military dominance," Stanford Brown's Mr Owen said.

He believed there was also a bigger risk on the horizon in the form of regulatory intervention.

"It's more the anti-trust movement against the Big Tech stocks, it's more of a medium-term concern," he said. "I think what will happen within five years is you'll see the big US tech stocks broken up."

The significance of the Big Tech companies to the US market means breaking them could have a broader destabilising impact.

Mr Owen was still optimistic despite those risks and with the 7000-point threshold now in sight, another key level is further away. Adjusted for inflation, the pre-GFC high for the S&P/ASX 200 is closer to 8800 points.

"The big target, which is the after-inflation target, it's another 27 per cent, which is a long way away," Mr Owen said.

Key pointsWith further monetary easing expected, the market is set to continue its firm run.

Analysts say there are risks that will determine if the growth is sustained.

urn:contentItem:5SD5-6MS1-DY19-C40P-00000-00ASX poised to drop at open2018-05-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:09ZLexisNexisASX poised to drop at openTimothy Moore

Australian shares are poised to drop at the open amid renewed tensions between the US and China.

Australian shares are poised to drop at the open amid renewed tensions between the US and China. ASX futures were 39 points lower at about 4am AEST. The Australian dollar edged 0.3 per cent higher.

The catalyst for the overnight shift in sentiment was an unexpected decision by President Donald Trump to cancel his planned June 12 meeting with North Korea's Kim Jong Un. He did so by citing what he called North Korea's "tremendous anger and open hostility" towards the US this week.

Separately Trump then said the US military stood ready to act as necessary.

"Our military, which is by far the most powerful anywhere in the world and has been greatly enhanced recently as you all know, is ready if necessary," Mr Trump said Friday AEST.

"Hopefully positive things will be taking place with respect to the future of North Korea, but if they don't we are more ready than we have ever been before."

He said that Japan and South Korea were willing to pay for American protection if military options proceeded.

Shares on Wall Street opened flat, checked by a slide in the price of oil, and then dropped. The Dow tumbled more than 250 points at one point before paring most of those losses by mid afternoon.

The yield on the US 10-year Treasury held below 3 per cent. The US dollar also retreated.

Today's Agenda

No local data

Overseas data: China industrial profits April; German IFO business climate May; UK first quarter GDP; US durable goods orders April, University of Michigan consumer sentiment May final

Market Highlights

SPI futures down 39 points or 0.7% to 6004 at about 4am AEST

AUD +0.3% to 75.79 US cents

On Wall St, at about 2pm: Dow -0.3%, S&P 500 -0.2%, Nasdaq flat

In New York, BHP -0.6% Rio -0.4%

In Europe: Stoxx 50 -0.6%, FTSE -0.9%, CAC -0.3%, DAX -0.9%

Spot gold +0.9% to $US1305.33 an ounce at 2.03pm New York time

Brent crude -1% to $US79.03 a barrel

US oil -1.3% to $US70.93 a barrel

Iron ore +3.5% to $US66.38 a tonne

Dalian iron ore +1% to 462 yuan

LME aluminium +0.4% to $US2280 a tonne

LME copper +0.2% to $US6880 a tonne

2-year bill yield: US 2.51%, Australia 2.01%

5-year note yield: US 2.82%, Australia 2.41%

10-year bond yield: US 2.98%, Australia 2.80%

From Today's Financial Review

When Trump bought Pratt dinner: Australia's richest man paid $US200,000 to become a member of Mar-a-Lago, Donald Trump's "winter White House". And it's been worth every penny for the cardboard king.

David Teoh throws all TPG's chips on the table: Betting against TPG Telecom's famously reclusive David Teoh has, in the past, been a fool's game.

RBA is the bond market's best friend: Interest rates appear to be on hold in Australia for the foreseeable future and that's a solid reason to buy Australian bonds, Morgan Stanley's Jim Caron says.

United States

US stocks fell on Thursday after President Donald Trump cancelled a planned historic summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and threatened tariffs on auto imports while trade tensions with China simmered.

Tech giants still offer value, says Capital: US mutual fund giant Capital Group is keeping faith with big tech companies despite increased regulatory concerns.

Market participants said the sharp drop after the summit was cancelled was a knee-jerk reaction.

"What we are seeing is a little more broad. We are at the mercy of the (Trump) administration, not just on North Korea but on trade with the auto tariffs," said Liz Ann Sonders, chief investment strategist at Charles Schwab, New York.

"Sure, the summit was seen as a positive and it being called off is, I suppose, a negative. But I think the weakness in the market is broader."

Oil prices recorded their largest one-day drop in two weeks, with expectations building that OPEC could wind down an output deal due to concerns about supplies from Venezuela and Iran.

Europe

European stocks fell on Thursday as carmaker shares came under pressure after the United States launched an investigation into auto imports, while Deutsche Bank dropped after announcing thousands of job cuts.

The STOXX 600 index fell 0.5 per cent to an eight-day low, reversing earlier gains as global equities came under pressure after US President Donald Trump cancelled a planned meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

Continued uncertainty over the make-up of the Italian government also weighed. Italy's FTSE MIB index fell 0.7 percent to a fresh 7-week low after coalition parties called for the naming of a eurosceptic economy minister.

German carmakers Daimler, BMW and Volkswagen dropped 1.7 to 2.8 per cent after the United States began a national security investigation into car and truck imports that could lead to new US tariffs.

Germany's benchmark DAX index fell 0.9 per cent and Europe's autos sector was the worst-performing, losing 1.8 per cent.

Deutsche Bank touched its lowest level since September 2016, ending 4.8 per cent down after saying it would cut thousands of staff in a revamp of its investment bank.

Jobs reductions announced on Thursday will reduce the number of full-time positions by at least 7000 from current levels to "well below" 90,000. The cuts may end up being closer to 10,000, according to a person with knowledge of the plans. The bank may be giving itself some room on the final number, which will also include reductions at the bank's largely German retail networks.

"Job cuts in itself are not a new strategy and they are also not value creating," Hans Christoph Hirt, head of Hermes EOS, which advises institutional investors in the bank, said on Bloomberg TV on Thursday in Frankfurt. "We would expect in due course, perhaps today, maybe in a few weeks or months, a much clearer strategy setting out what exactly will change and how Deutsche Bank will create value for shareholders in the foreseeable future again."

Asia

Defusing China's ticking debt bomb: There are two triggers which could set off China's ticking debt bomb.

Currencies

Peak tightening may be closer than you think: The current pace of Fed hikes implies a six- to nine-month horizon, analysts warn.

Capital Economics on the euro: "With both relative interest rate expectations and rates of economic growth moving in the euro's direction, we expect it to make headway against the dollar. Our end-2019 forecast is $1.30/???, compared to $1.17/??? now."

Commodities

Marex Spectron's take on the LME: "The [US] dollar retreated from yesterday's multi-year high and most base metals picked up in the afternoon to settle unchanged to modestly higher with evidence of some real money buying into the close. TIN was the exception, closing down 1.2% as LME on-warrant stocks continued to rise to 2365t, the highest level seen since April 2017. LEAD and NICKEL meanwhile were the outperformers and the only metals to register above average turnover.

"NICKEL - picked up sharply as the SHFE evening session opened along with turnover, to settle at the highs of the session at $14,900 (+1.7%). This is back to levels not seen since 20th April (nb the day prior Nickel had reached a high of $16,690). Noticeably the $15k mark is also where 1.4k lots of combined OI sits for June. By 17:30, 5.9k lots had traded, +5% on the 20-day average. We noted CTA type buying during the day. Nickel exhibits the largest long of the complex on our estimates at 17.5% of OI (cob Tues). The year-to-date peak long sits at 22% of OI from the end of Jan. SHFE agg OI jumped to 779k lots last, up 83k lots since yesterday morning and the highest level since 23rd March."

Chinese steel and iron ore futures closed higher for the first time in seven sessions on Thursday on expectation that the recent sell-off has reached its limit.

The most-traded steel rebar contract, for October delivery, on the Shanghai Futures Exchange recovered from an early fall to close 1.2 per cent higher at 3583 yuan ($US561.19) a tonne. Iron ore futures on the Dalian Commodity Exchange rose 1.1 per cent to 459.5 yuan a tonne.

Rebar fell in five of the previous six sessions and was unchanged on May 17, amid lukewarm demand in the spot market, while iron ore had slipped on all six previous trading days.

Spot steel product prices fell 0.5 per cent to 4276.22 yuan a tonne on Wednesday, a level not seen for nearly three weeks, data from Mysteel consultancy showed.

"Iron ore prices have already fallen to a low level... and the market thinks there is only limited room for prices to decline further," analysts at CITIC Futures said in a note.

Australian Sharemarket

Stockpickers see spark in markets, kick off Firetrail funds: Former Macquarie Group star stockpickers Patrick Hodgens and Blake Henricks see an abundance of opportunities across equity markets, as they kick off a $7.5 billion raising across two new boutique funds.

Australian shares have avoided a sixth straight loss despite the major banks continuing to weigh on the market.

The S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 4.6 points, or 0.1 per cent, to 6037.1 as Commonwealth Bank led the market losses following its appearance at the royal commission.

At the commission on Thursday, it was revealed Commonwealth Bank had made a slew of errors, including charging double interest on around 2,500 simple business overdrafts.

The commission found it took CBA on average 960 days from the time double-charging first started to customers being compensated. Commonwealth Bank shares closed down 0.3 per cent at $69.59.

Street Talk

Private equity takes second look at Greencross

What Deutsche Bank's global job cuts target means for Aus

NSW windfarm finds Partners for $250m deal

with Reuters, Bloomberg, AAP

Comments? Questions? Let us know what you think of Before the Bell: timothy.moore@fairfaxmedia.com.au

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RX9-3NK1-DY19-C150-00000-00ASX poised to open flat, Fed awaited2018-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:09ZLexisNexisASX poised to open flat, Fed awaitedTimothy Moore

Australian shares are poised to open flat to slightly higher as global investors head for the sidelines ahead of an expected lift in US rates.

Australian shares are poised to open flat to slightly higher as global investors head for the sidelines ahead of an expected lift in US rates. ASX futures were up 8 points or 0.1 per cent at about 5am AEDT. The Australian dollar slipped 0.4 per cent.

Trading in New York was mixed, with investors turning cautious ahead of the conclusion of a policy meeting at the Federal Reserve. The central bank is widely expected to announce a rate hike in a statement early tomorrow morning Australian time.

Soon after the decision is announced, Jerome Powell will host his first news conference as chairman.

Mr Powell will have a chance to signal his take on how markets are moving as a rout in Facebook tests investors' long bets on the tech sector.

The latest Bank of America Merrill Lynch fund manager survey found that long big tech holdings were the most crowded trade this month.

The survey, released overnight, found that "cracks in the bull case" were emerging, specifically concerns over a potential trade war, stagflation and leverage.

However, the survey also found: "Ominously investors [have] yet to act on [their] fears."

Investors continued to be "stubbornly long global stocks, banks, tech, still short bonds, defensives, and cash levels fell from 4.7 per cent to 4.6 per cent, the survey found. Average cash for the past decade is 4.5 per cent. The allocation to banks reached its second highest on record.

When asked what yield the 10-year US Treasury note needed to reach to trigger a rotation from stocks into bonds, the respondents said 3.60 per cent. That's 72 basis points higher than where they are trading in New York overnight. For context, the yield has risen 42 basis points so far this year. The yield peaked at 2.95 per cent on February 21.

Today's Agenda

Local data: WBC Leading Index February, Skilled Vacancies February

Overseas data: Euro zone consumer confidence March; UK jobless claims change February, ILO unemployment rate January; US existing home sales February, Fed rate decision

Market Highlights

SPI futures up 8 points or 0.1% to 5931 at about 5am AEDT

AUD -0.4% to 76.89 US cents

On Wall St: Dow +0.4%, S&P 500 -0.1%, Nasdaq flat

In New York, Facebook -5.7%, Twitter -11.3%, Snap -4.4%

In Europe: Stoxx 50 +0.5%, FTSE +0.3%, CAC +0.6%, DAX +0.7%

Spot gold -0.4% to $US1311.86 an ounce

Brent crude +2% to $US67.39 a barrel

US oil +2.1% to $US63.39 a barrel

Iron ore -0.8% to $US66.94 a tonne

Dalian iron ore +1.5% to 466 yuan

LME aluminium -0.6% to $US2076 a tonne

LME copper -1.4% to $US6755 a tonne

10-year bond yield: US 2.88%, Germany 0.58%, Australia 2.70%

From Today's Financial Review

Labor moves to head off tax plan backlash: Labor is leaning towards exempting low-income pensioners from its policy to scrap franking credit refunds in order to head off a backlash from retirees.

Chanticleer   : Experts play down Uber, Facebook setbacks: Credit Suisse's bullish attitude to tech investment has worked well, but will Uber and Facebook's woes dent enthusiasm for tech stocks?

O'Dwyer warns super funds on life insurance erosion: Kelly O'Dwyer is increasingly frustrated with the lack of action from Australia's super funds on life insurance.

United States

US stocks rose on Tuesday as a jump in oil prices lifted energy stocks, though another drop in Facebook's shares curbed the gains on the Nasdaq Composite and the S&P.

Facebook's shares fell 5.2 per cent on a Bloomberg report that the US Federal Trade Commission was investigating the company over its use of personal data after a whistleblower said a political consultancy improperly accessed information on 50 million users to sway public opinion.

The stock sank almost 7 per cent on Monday, sparking a broad sell-off. US and European lawmakers have demanded an explanation of how the consultancy gained access to the data and why Facebook failed to inform its users, raising broader industry questions about consumer privacy.

Shares of Snap fell nearly 4 per cent, while Twitter's shares tumbled 9.2 per cent. The S&P technology index was down 0.2 per cent.

"Not all the overhang has cleared, there's still some anxiety. But as a whole, we still think the space has a lot of upside and are constructive on tech," said Josh Navarro, global investment specialist at J.P. Morgan Private Bank.

Europe

European stocks recovered on Tuesday, led by banking stocks while tech stayed under pressure after concerns over increased regulation and taxation of large companies in the sector prompted selling overnight on Wall Street.

The pan-European STOXX 600 index ended 0.5 per cent higher, while Britain's FTSE rose 0.3 per cent after hitting a 15-month low in the previous session.

Europe's tech stocks lagged the market, though they managed a 0.4 per cent rise having lost more than 1.5 per cent in the previous session. The sector remains the biggest gainer in Europe over the last 12 months.

Strong financials meanwhile helped offset weakness among media and telecoms stocks.

Support from Publicis evaporated as its shares turned lower following early gains of as much as 3 per cent as analysts showed a mixed reception to its new business plan in a challenging advertising market.

British software company Micro Focus fell another 1.9 per cent, having lost 46.3 per cent in the previous session after its CEO quit and it cut its revenue outlook. More than half a dozen analysts cut their price targets on Micro Focus.

Asia

Hong Kong stocks were little changed on Tuesday, as investors braced for Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's first policy meeting starting later in the day and amid concerns that U.S. President Donald Trump could impose additional punitive trade measures against China.

The Hang Seng index rose 0.1 per cent to 31,549.93, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.5 per cent to 12,597.42 points.

China's main Shanghai Composite index closed up 0.3 per cent at 3290.64, while the blue-chip CSI300 index was up 0.08 per cent at 4077.70.

Japan's Nikkei share average fell on Tuesday as domestic tech stocks tracked US counterparts' declines on Wall Street, but declines were limited as investors refrained from taking large positions before the Federal Reserve meeting.

The Nikkei dropped 0.5 per cent to 21,380.97. The broader Topix shed 0.2 per cent to 1716.29.

Many investors stayed on the sidelines ahead of a Japanese public holiday and the two-day Fed meeting expected to produce a rate hike.

The Fed decision and views on the path ahead will be known before Asian markets open on Thursday.

Currencies

With a rate increase a foregone conclusion when the Federal Reserve concludes its two-day policy meeting on Wednesday, traders have been actively pricing it in. The three-month US dollar London interbank offered rate, or Libor, which is one of the benchmarks for setting borrowing rates worldwide, has been on the rise since February 7, reaching 2.25 per cent, the highest since 2008. Meanwhile, its gap over similar-maturity risk-free rates, known as the Libor-OIS spread, has more than doubled since the end of January to 55 basis points, a level unseen since 2009.

Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell and his colleagues will end up raising interest rates four times this year, but are unlikely to signal that intention at this week's policy meeting, according to economists surveyed by Bloomberg.

In a poll of 41 economists conducted by Bloomberg March 13-16, the median forecast predicted a quarter-point hike this week, plus similar moves in June and September and December. At the same time, respondents said policy makers will continue to pencil in three rate increases as being likely in 2018 in their updated quarterly forecasts.

Pricing in federal funds futures contracts currently implies about a 35 per cent probability of four increases or more in 2018, up from less than 10 per cent three months ago. The probability of a rate increase this week is seen at about 100 per cent.

Commodities

Rio sells Hail Creek to Glencore for $2.2b: Rio Tinto has sold its Hail Creek and Valeria coal assets in Queensland to Glencore for $2.2 billion, in a deal that increases the Swiss miner's dominance of Australian coal.

Three-month LME copper closed 1.4 per cent down at $US6755 a tonne, marking a fourth session of losses. It had dipped as low as $US6730, its weakest level since December 14.

Zinc fell 1.8 per cent to finish at $US3203 a tonne. LME zinc stocks have shot up by 60 per cent this month, climbing by another 5350 tonnes on Tuesday to 211,400 tonnes.

LME aluminium fell by 0.6 per cent to close at $US2076 a tonne, with losses moderating after Japanese buyers agreed to pay producers premiums during the second quarter that are 25 per cent higher than the previous quarter, reflecting rising spot premiums in the United States.

Lead dropped 0.7 per cent to close at $US2351 a tonne, nickel lost 0.2 per cent to $US13,450 and tin was down 0.5 per cent at $US20,675.

Chinese iron ore prices fell further on Tuesday, a day after posting their biggest daily drop in almost 10 months as high inventories and a weak domestic steel market pressure prices.

Near-term inventory risks have dampened the outlook for steel and iron ore prices short term, Argonaut said in a report, despite a relatively healthy global demand outlook.

Steel inventories stood at 19.5 million tonnes last week, slightly lower than the previous week, but remain at the highest level since 2014, Argonaut noted. Meanwhile, stockpiles of imported iron ore at ports stayed at 159.18 million tonnes, in line with last week's record.

"The record port inventory (has become) a key overhang over short-term," Argonaut said.

Australian Sharemarket

Australian shares fell for the first time in three sessions on Tuesday, as some heavy losses in the mining sector outweighed a better day for the banks in a week where traders are bracing for a rate hike from the US Federal Reserve.

The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 23 points, or 0.4 per cent, to 5936 while the All Ordinaries index declined by the same amount in points and percentage terms to trade at 6040.

Tuesday's ASX losses aside, Nikko Asset Management's chief global strategist John Vail said he expects Australian equities to perform very well this year due to strong global growth, reasonable equity valuations, decent earnings growth and continued low global interest rates.

However, protectionist actions by the US will need to be watched very carefully, he said.

Street Talk

ANZ Bank wealth, life insurance suitors tango with staff ahead of split

Sony Life on the back foot for ClearView Wealth tilt, as transaction clock ticks

Private equity, trade buyers eye radiology firm; KPMG hired

with Reuters, Bloomberg, AAP

Comments? Questions? Let us know what you think of Before the Bell: timothy.moore@fairfaxmedia.com.au

urn:contentItem:5S5B-FV61-JBJ7-N4BD-00000-00ASX set to fall amid Hayne fallout2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:09ZLexisNexisASX set to fall amid Hayne falloutTimothy Moore

Australian shares appear poised to start the week lower after metals eased and amid expected further fallout from the Hayne royal commission.

Australian shares appear poised to start the week lower after metals eased and amid expected further fallout from the Hayne royal commission. ASX futures were down 15 points or 0.3 per cent. The Australian dollar fell 0.8 per cent, tumbling back below US77??.

One weekend development that could impact early trade was news from North Korea that it has suspended nuclear weapon and long-range missile tests. That statement comes ahead of a meeting of the leaders of the two Koreas and as North Korea and the US work towards a meeting between Kim Jong Un and Donald Trump.

While positive in global geopolitical terms, the promise of an easing of tensions on the Korean peninsula isn't likely to have much of a market impact.

In a shortened week - with the ASX closed on Wednesday for ANZAC Day, the local focus this morning will be on AMP and the rest of Australia's financial industry. Revelations from the Hayne commission made last week a horror one for the sector. AMP has been left in tatters; it has shed more than 20 per cent from March 8.

Also likely to dent sentiment as the week begins is a retracing of recent advances in aluminium, copper, nickel and iron ore. Strategists are generally positive on the outlook for commodities as the global economy accelerates toward its peak for this cycle, though they say some prices have overshot near term.

Aluminium, for one, surged more than 30 per cent in the wake of the latest raft of US sanctions on Russia including aluminium producer Rusal. TD Securities said aluminium, now in "overbought territory", could be in for "a technically inspired move lower to $US2360 a tonne".

Concerns, some misplaced, also drove nickel to multi-year highs last week and it too could see its price backtrack in the days ahead.

The surge in commodity prices has renewed the debate about the outlook for inflation and Australia's all-imporant consumer price index report for the first quarter, set to be released tomorrow, is the key data point this week.

NAB is expecting a rise between 0.4 and 0.5 per cent quarter over quarter, or 1.9 per cent year over year. For core inflation, NAB expects 0.5 per cent quarter over quarter for the trimmed mean and 0.4 per cent quarter over quarter for the weighted median.

"For headline inflation, [the first quarter] is often boosted by seasonal price increases," NAB economist Kaixin Owyong wrote in a week-ahead note, reflecting start of the calendar year increases in health, school and utility prices.

Ms Owyong said an outcome of around 0.4-0.5 per cent quarter over quarter for core inflation "doesn't give the RBA any reason to lift rates early, and is likely to leave the bank in its current 'wait and watch' setting".

"Given the backdrop of a strengthening global and Australian economy, and an unemployment rate forecast to decline, any downside surprise to core inflation is more likely to delay RBA interest rate hikes, rather than be a signpost for a potential further interest rate cut," Ms Owyong also said.

Australian investors also will be keeping a watch over the US corporate earnings season which will gather pace this week with a particular focus on technology shares. Wall Street stumbled to end last week as earnings, while mostly strong, disappointed.

Reporting this week are Facebook, Alphabet, Amazon, Microsoft as well as Twitter. Apple, which saw its shares drop last week on concerns that global smartphone sales have perhaps peaked - according to the International Monetary Fund, reports on May 1.

Today's Agenda

No local data

Overseas data: Japan Nikkei manufacturing April; Euro zone Markit manufacturing and services PMIs for April; US Markit manufacturing and services PMIs for April, Chicago Fed activity index March, Existing home sales March

Market Highlights

SPI futures down 15 points or 0.3% to 5833

AUD flat at 76.70 US cents

On Wall St: Dow -0.8%, S&P 500 -0.9%, Nasdaq -1.3%

In New York, BHP -0.1% Rio +0.1%

In Europe: Stoxx 50 +0.2%, FTSE +0.5%, CAC +0.4%, DAX -0.2%

Spot gold -0.7% to $US1336.36 an ounce

Brent crude +0.4% to $US74.06 a barrel

US oil -0.4% to $US68.06 a barrel

Iron ore -2% to $US67.09 a tonne

Dalian iron ore -0.6% to 464 yuan

LME aluminium -0.6% to $US2469 a tonne.

LME copper -0.1% to $US6992 a tonne

10-year bond yield: US 2.96%, Germany 0.59%, Australia 2.80%

From Today's Financial Review

A group of angry American shareholders say they want the Macquarie Infrastructure board sacked and the company liquidated. Read the full story here.

A former Westpac financial planner castigated by the royal commission for ripping off clients claims he has been made a scapegoat by the bank, which "squeezed" him for revenue while slashing support staff. Full story here.

Plenty of Australian companies have blown up shareholder money when venturing overseas but Platypus fund manager Prasad Patkar has backed many of the ones who have had succeeded and says there's no room for ego when considering an overseas expansion. Read story here.

Malcolm Turnbull says Australia will not agree to a free trade agreement with Europe that restricts access for agriculture but stresses a deal is needed to send a message to a world afflicted by rising protectionism and a disregard for the rules-based order. Full story here.

United States

US stocks stumbled into the weekend, as renewed selling in technology shares overshadowed what has so far been a solid earnings season.

Makers of computer chips and hardware bore the brunt of the selling, with Apple capping for its biggest rout since early February following a downgrade based on its deteriorating outlook in China. Trade also remains in focus, with the US Treasury considering an emergency law to curb Chinese investments in sensitive technologies.

General Electric rose on solid results, one of just four gainers in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The company joined the 85 per cent of S&P 500 companies that've topped earnings estimates so far this season by an average of 7.1 per cent.

Alphabet, Google's parent, reports on Monday (Tuesday AEST) in what will be one of the busiest weeks for first-quarter results. Facebook (Thursday AEST) and Amazon (Friday AEST) also report this week. Also reporting in the days ahead are Twitter and Qualcomm on Thursday AEST, and Intel and Microsoft on Friday AEST.

"Investor sentiment with tech stocks is in a long, slow retreat," said Jake Dollarhide, chief executive officer of Longbow Asset Management in Tulsa, Oklahoma. "If guidance is significantly more optimistic than what was expected, they might get a pop on that, but anything negative will be disastrous."

Analysts on average expect S&P 500 information technology companies to grow their earnings per share by nearly 24 per cent, which is better than the 20 per cent growth estimated across the S&P 500, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.

The S&P 500 information technology index is trading at about 18 times expected earnings, down from nearly 20 in late January but still above its 15-year average of 17, according to Thomson Reuters Datastream.

Europe

The pan-European STOXX 600 index ended Friday's session flat in percentage terms, while rising 0.7 per cent on the week, its fourth straight week of gains, as global markets recovered from a turbulent first quarter.

Jitters over possible trade wars, faster rate hikes in the United States and a regulatory crackdown on big tech groups sent the STOXX to 14-month lows in March.

But since April the index has been on a recovery path as those worries receded and investors were lured back into equities by cheaper company valuations.

While moves were largely muted at the index level on Friday, Ericsson surged 17.5 per cent and posted its biggest one-day gain since October 2002 after the Swedish mobile equipment maker reported first-quarter earnings and its gross margin above market expectations as cost savings from job cuts started to kick in.

Its gains drove shares in rival Nokia up 2.4 per cent.

Shares in Shire were the worst FTSE performers, down nearly 4 per cent after Botox maker Allergan walked away from a bid for the rare-disease drugs specialist.

On Friday, Japan's Takeda increased its offer for the rare-disease drugs specialist to 47 pounds-a-share. Shire has rejected Takeda's previous three offers.

Asia

China stocks fell on Friday to have their worst week in a month, amid lingering worries over the simmering trade tensions between China and the United States. The blue-chip CSI300 index closed down 1.3 per cent at 3760.85, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.5 per cent to 3071.54. For the week, CSI300 declined 2.9 per cent, while SSEC shed 2.8 per cent, both logging their worst week since late March.

Caution prevailed as worries persisted over the trade stand-off between China and the United States.

China's ZTE said on Friday a ban on the sale of parts and software to the company was unfair and threatens its survival, and vowed to safeguard its interests through all legal means. ZTE stock is still suspended in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The ZTE ban has ratchetted up tensions between China and the United States at a time when they have already threatened each other with tens of billions of dollars in tariffs.

Hong Kong stocks ended down on Friday, as energy shares slumped from a two-month high hit in the previous session, while technology stocks tracked the Asian tech sector lower. The Hang Seng index ended down 0.9 per cent at 30,418.33, while the China Enterprises Index closed 1.5 per cent down at 12,054.23 points.

Japan's Nikkei share average edged lower on Friday morning as worries about slower smartphone demand hit technology shares, while financial stocks rallied thanks to higher US yields.

The Nikkei gave up 0.1 per cent to 22,162.24. The index rose 1.8 per cent for the week, its fourth straight week of gains.

Semiconductor equipment companies and electronic component makers underperformed after Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd, the world's largest contract chipmaker, revised its full-year revenue target to the low end of its previous forecast due to softer demand for smartphones.

Tokyo Electron tumbled 2.1 per cent, Advantest Corp declined 2.2 per cent, while Murata Manufacturing shed 2.0 per cent, TDK Corp fell 1.4 per cent and Alps Electric dropped 1.8 per cent.

Rising U.S. yields, however, benefited financials which are exposed to high-yielding products such as foreign bonds. Insurer Dai-ichi Life surged 2.0 per cent and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group added 0.7 per cent.

The broader Topix gained 0.1 per cent to 1751.13

Currencies

Treasuries traders have a new level to focus on: the pivotal 3 per cent mark on 10-year notes.

After the benchmark yield plowed to a new 2018 peak just shy of 2.96 per cent on Friday in New York - its highest since January 2014, chart watchers are turning their gaze to the next round number on the horizon.

"We'll be heading to 3 per cent pretty quickly now," said Peter Tchir, head of macro strategy at Academy Securities. "Moving above 3 per cent though will be tough, as there are resistance points around 3.05 percent. This rise in the long-end yields should take some more pressure off the curve-flattening trend."

The spread between 2- and 10-year yields has risen for three straight sessions, rebounding from just 41 basis points on Wednesday, the smallest gap in more than a decade. The spread was just shy of 50 basis points Friday.

Speculators' net short dollar position surged to the highest since August 2011 in the latest week, according to calculations by Reuters and Commodity Futures Trading Commission data released on Friday. The value of the net short dollar position was $US23.42 billion in the week ended April 17, compared with net shorts of $US22.77 billion the previous week. Short-term investors have been short the dollar since mid-July last year.

"There was not one, but four main catalysts for the US dollar's recovery this past week," said Kathy Lien, managing director of FX strategy, at BK Asset Management in New York. She cited the rise in Treasury yields, softer global data, solid US retail sales and a more upbeat Beige Book report, including a generally quiet environment on the geopolitical front. Investors were overall relieved that President Donald Trump did not escalate tensions in Syria after striking specific targets in that country, instead abandoning plans for more sanctions.

"If President Trump stays relatively quiet, US data beats (forecasts) and 10-year Treasury yields edge closer to 3 per cent, the US dollar can extend its gains," Lien added.

Commodities

Go long commodities ahead of global economic peak: Investors can still profit from some well-timed commodity bets, strategists say, even though some prices have overshot near term.

Chinese iron ore prices fell on Friday after a nearly 7-per cent jump in the previous session, ending their strongest week since December on expectations of rising demand for restocking at steel mills.

The most-active iron ore futures on the Dalian Commodity Exchange eased 1 percent to 461 yuan ($US73.37) a tonne after a sharp rally in the previous session, but still marked their strongest weekly gain in 17 weeks.

"The market has been in a party mood since the central bank said it was cutting (bank reserve requirements). On a fundamental basis, the market expects some restocking demand for raw materials since mills have incentives to churn out output amid fat margins," said a Shanghai-based iron ore trader.

Average output profits at steel mills are currently around 681 yuan a tonne in top steelmaking city Tangshan, according to Mysteel consultancy.

Construction rebar contracts for October delivery on the Shanghai Futures Exchange dropped 1.1 per cent to 3454 yuan a tonne. They have gained 10 per cent over the past three weeks.

China's domestic iron ore output shrank in the first quarter of 2018 amid weaker prices for the material, Metal Bulletin reported. The country produced 189.46 million tonnes of run-of-mine (ROM) iron ore in the three months to March 31, down 1.9 per cent year on year, according to the latest data from the National Bureau of Statistics.

Australian Sharemarket

A loss on Friday wasn't enough to hinder an otherwise positive performance on the Australian market last week as the index recorded its third consecutive weekly gain.

The S&P/ASX 200 index was down 12.2 points on Friday to 5868.8, but up 39.7 points for the week.

The mining sector was the best performer this week, supported by improving prices in commodities including multi-year highs for aluminium and nickel.

Street Talk

with Reuters, Bloomberg, AAP

Comments? Questions? Let us know what you think of Before the Bell: timothy.moore@fairfaxmedia.com.au

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RSW-RC81-DY19-C088-00000-00ASX set to rise amid more volatility2018-03-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:09ZLexisNexisASX set to rise amid more volatilityTimothy Moore

Australian shares appear poised to open higher, though they need be ready for more fluctuations.

Australian shares appear poised to open higher, rebounding from their worst session in three weeks, though they need be positioned for more volatility as geopolitical risks return and before a wave of local economic data.

The key focus this week will be the Reserve Bank's policy decision tomorrow. While there is no expectation the RBA will move interest rates until later in the year, investors will be keen to see if the central bank provides any fresh perspective on wages and the outlook for the economy before the release of fourth-quarter GDP on Wednesday.

Investors also will be paying close attention to a speech by governor Philip Lowe at the AFR Business Summit at 8.35am on Wednesday for his view on investment trends.

What central banks plan to do this year and next have taken on heightened importance as the global bull market for equities is being tested.

After recouping most of the losses incurred in last month's correction, equities were knocked last week by President Donald Trump's comments that the US would impose tariffs on steel and aluminium imports, signalling his intent to adopt the protectionist trade stance he espoused during his presidential election campaign. More details could be announced this week. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said Mr Trump appeared to be leaning towards a global tariff with no exemptions for any country.

Mr Trump made clear in two tweets on Friday in the US that he was going to "protect" the country. The tweets triggered yet more volatility in New York, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunging near 400 points before paring most of the losses. Both the Standard & Poor's 500 and the Nasdaq Composite ended higher, erasing earlier losses. The VIX, Wall Street's measure of investors' fear, swung in a wide range before ending lower.

The yield on the US 10-year note retraced its previous session drop to rise 6 basis points to 2.87 per cent. The spot dollar index edged lower; the Australian dollar edged higher.

"Geopolitical risks are rising in the context of a market that has been priced for Goldilocks," Tematica Research's chief macro strategist Lenore Hawkins said in her end of week note.

On Friday in New York, the Dow was 0.3 per cent lower. The S&P 500 was rose 0.5 per cent and the Nasdaq was up 1.1 per cent. The US listed shares of BHP Billiton slid 0.6 per cent, while Rio Tinto fell 2.2 per cent. ASX futures were up 12 points at about 9am AEDT Saturday. The ASX had its worst session in three weeks on Friday.

Another $US6 trillion equity market correction lies ahead for global equities, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch strategists led by Michael Hartnett in a March 1 dated report, saying the topping process has started.

That call reflects that bullishness, the outlook for corporate profits and central bank policy are each peaking. BAML's Bull & Bear indicator is at 7.6, or no longer the sell signal it was several weeks ago.

In addition, the strategists said protectionism is starting, global equities are no longer outperforming global government bonds and big tech is not making new highs. Finally, they said the trough in inflation, rates and volatility ??? all 9-year drivers of the bull market in corporate bonds and equities ??? is now challenging the bullish consensus.

Today's Agenda

Local data: AiG performance of services February, MI inflation February, Business indicators fourth quarter: Company profits, Building approvals January, ANZ job ads February

Overseas data: China Caixin services PMI February; Euro zone retail sales January; UK Markit services PMI February; US ISM non-manufacturing February

Market Highlights

SPI futures up 12 points or 0.2% to 5924

AUD +0.1% to 77.61 US cents

On Wall St: Dow -0.3%, S&P 500 +0.5%, Nasdaq +1.1%

In New York, BHP -0.6% Rio -2.2%

In Europe: Stoxx 50 -2.2%, FTSE -1.5%, CAC -2.4%, DAX -2.3%

Spot gold +0.4% to $US1322.16 an ounce

Brent crude +1.1% to $US64.53 a barrel

US oil +0.8% to $US61.45 a barrel

Iron ore -1.3% to $US78.34 a tonne

Dalian iron ore -1.6% to 531 yuan

LME aluminium +0.1% to $US2149 a tonne

LME copper -0.4% to $US6898 a tonne

10-year bond yield: US 2.86%, Germany 0.65%, Australia 2.73%

From Today's Financial Review

Trump's tariff trade war hits home

76pc of Caltex franchises exploiting workers

Amazon, Uber are bad for consumers

United States

US stocks ended a volatile session higher, paring a weekly decline, as investors speculated that President Donald Trump's tough tariff talk won't translate into the most severe protectionist policies.

The S&P 500 Index staged a late-day rally to finish near its high for the session. The gain trimmed its weekly decline to 2 percent. The Dow Jones Industrial Average roared back to all but erase a drop that approached 400 points at its worst.

The threat of a trade war sparked the early selling, only to ease as the president's recent history of backing off seemingly iron-clad policy positions gave rise to speculation the actual levies may not disrupt global growth.

"People always forget that Trump is a negotiator, and when you negotiate, you don't negotiate from the point where you want it to end up --- you put an anchor out, and you negotiate from that anchor," said Brent Schutte, chief investment strategist of Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Co.'s wealth-management unit "Yesterday was an anchor. I do believe there will be some give back if others are willing to give the U.S. something."

Billionaire Steve Schwarzman dominates Wall Street with his annual payouts, collecting $US787 million last year. He turned around and put a quarter of that back into Blackstone Group. The asset manager disclosed Thursday that its co-founder, 71, invested $US196.6 million in Blackstone funds during 2017. That compares with the $US161.8 million that Carlyle Group LP's Bill Conway invested in his firm's offerings, $US43.3 million by KKR & Co's Henry Kravis and $US15 million by Apollo Global Management LLC's Marc Rowan.

This week's US domestic economic data includes factory orders, international trade data, the EIA Petroleum Status Report, the Fed's Beige Book, and the closely-watched nonfarm payrolls report for February.

Europe

European shares fell to six-month lows on Friday. The pan-European STOXX 600 benchmark was down 2.1 per cent, surpassing a low hit in early February during a brutal sell-off in global equities.

The STOXX ended the week down 3.7 per cent ahead of events this Sunday in Italy and Germany that could raise new jitters over the political future of Europe, as Brexit talks with the UK continue.

The European Union is considering applying 25 per cent tariffs on around $US3.5 billion of imports from the United States if President Donald Trump carries out his plan to apply global duties to steel and aluminum, EU sources say.

Britain's Royal Bank of Scotland could reach a multi billion-dollar settlement with the US Department of Justice over its mis-selling of toxic mortgage-backed securities within weeks, Sky News reported on Friday, citing sources.

Prime Minister Theresa May urged the European Union on Friday to show more flexibility in talks on a future relationship after Brexit, saying Britain realised it could not get all it wanted but believed an ambitious trade deal was still possible.

In a much-anticipated speech, May set out ambitions for a tailor-made free trade deal that would include financial services and said Britain would aim for associate membership of EU regulators covering chemicals, medicines and aerospace.

Jettisoning an earlier strident view that Britain could walk away from the talks, May appealed to the EU to work together to solve some of the more difficult Brexit problems, including over Ireland, where some fear the return of a "hard border" with the British province of Northern Ireland after Brexit.

Her vision was little changed from an earlier proposal for Britain to be able to diverge from some of the EU's rules and regulations while sticking to others which benefit Britain, a plan the bloc has described as "pure illusion".

Asia

Hong Kong stocks fell the most in three weeks on Friday, bringing the week's loss to over 2 per cent, as concerns of a global trade war hit already shaky confidence due to prospects of a faster pace of US monetary tightening.

The Hang Seng index fell 1.5 per cent, to 30,583.45, while the China Enterprises Index lost 1.8 per cent to 12,203.91 points. Major Chinese steelmaker Angang Steel fell over 2 per cent, Maanshan Iron lost nearly 5 per cent while Aluminum Corp of China was down 2.6 per cent.

China's blue-chip CSI300 index fell 0.8 per cent to 4016.46 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.6 per cent to 3254.53.

Japanese stocks fell to a 2-1/2-week low on Friday, with steelmakers and automakers taking a battering. The ratio of shares sold short hit a record high of 48.8 per cent.

Investors also got a jolt on comments from Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda that the central bank will consider an exit from easy policy if its inflation target is achieved during fiscal 2019.

The Nikkei ended 2.5 per cent lower to 21,181.64 points, the lowest closing level since February 14. The index dropped 3.2 per cent last week.

The broader Topix dropped 1.8 per cent to 1708.34, with all of its 33 subsectors falling.

"The market has been very sensitive about BOJ's exit from ultra easy policy," said Norihiro Fujito, senior investment strategist at Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities. "Until now, the BOJ did not comment on exiting, but since it was reported that he commented on exiting, the market was startled."

Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp dropped 3.8 per cent, JFE Holdings fell 2.8 per cent and Kobe Steel declined 2.7 per cent. Honda Motor tumbled 3.8 per cent, Toyota Motor dropped 2.4 per cent, Subaru shed 2.1 per cent, Nissan Motor declined 1.4 per cent and Mazda Motor tanked 2.9 per cent.

Currencies

Speculators' net short US dollar bets rose to a three-week high in the latest week, according to calculations by Reuters and Commodity Futures Trading Commission data released on Friday.

The value of the net short US dollar positions, derived from net positions of International Monetary Market speculators in the yen, euro, British pound, Swiss franc and Canadian and Australian dollars, was $US11.29 billion in the week to February 27. That compares with a net short position of $US8.17 billion the previous week. To be short a currency means traders believe it will fall in value.

Net long positioning on the euro rose to 137,977 contracts, after three straight weeks of declines.

Speculators' net short position on bitcoin Cboe futures rose to 1833 contracts, up from a net short position of 1608 contracts in the prior week, the data showed.

Kuroda on the Bank of Japan's policy path: " "The BOJ's board members expect that prices will reach 2 percent around fiscal 2019. If this happens, there's no doubt that we will consider and debate an exit."

While Kuroda's remarks were broadly consistent with his previous guidance on the conditions needed to unwind the accommodative policy, market participants took particular note of his explicit reference to "an exit". This stoked speculation the BOJ could follow in the footsteps of its major peers in removing monetary stimulus.

"The market has been very sensitive about the BOJ's exit from ultra-easy policy," said Norihiro Fujito, senior investment strategist at Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities. "Until now, the BOJ did not comment on exiting, but since it was reported that he commented on exiting, the market was startled."

Kuroda, who has been nominated by the government to serve another five-year term after his current one ends in April, made the comments during a confirmation hearing at the lower house of parliament on Friday.

Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities expects that the BOJ won't tighten policy at least until some time in 2020 as the central bank should examine the impact of a planned sales tax hike in October 2019.

With inflation remaining distant from the 2 per cent target, the central bank is widely expected to keep its massive monetary easing intact at its policy-setting meeting this week.

Commodities

Three-month aluminium on the London Metal Exchange ended up 0.1 per cent at $US2149 a tonne, bucking a mostly falling trend in base metals. Aluminium on the Shanghai Futures Exchange (ShFE) closed down 0.1 per cent after touching a two-week high.

Copper ended down 0.4 per cent at $US6898 a tonne, zinc closed down 1.5 per cent at $US3355, lead closed up 0.1 per cent at $US2448, tin ended down 0.8 per cent at $US21,475 while nickel ended down 0.2 per cent at $US13,450.

Chinese steel futures retreated on Friday after a five-day rally, though traders pointed more to rising inventories than the US tariff plans.

The most-active rebar on the Shanghai Futures Exchange closed down 0.3 per cent at 4024 yuan ($US634) a tonne, after touching a nearly three-year peak of 4062 yuan on Thursday.

Expectations that more Chinese cities could curb steel output after top steel-producing Tangshan announced it would extend production restrictions beyond the end of the heating season on March 15 had buoyed steel prices this week, with raw materials iron ore and coking coal also hitting multi-week highs.

But steel's pullback on Friday also weighed on iron ore and coking coal prices.

The spot price for iron ore fell 1.3 per cent to $US78.34 a tonne, according to Metal Bulletin.

US drillers added 1 oil rig in the week to March 2, bringing the total count to 800, the highest level since April 2015, Baker Hughes said in its closely followed report.

Australian Sharemarket

The Australian sharemarket finished the week 1.2 per cent lower as the threat of a trade war erupted from Washington and reverberated around the globe.

The S&P/ASX 200 Index closed the session with a drop of 44 points or 0.7 per cent, to 5928.9 points on Friday, its worst session in three weeks. The NZX 50 fell 0.65 per cent to 8288 points.

Morgan Stanley's post-results season view: "166 companies reported full-year and interim results through February, representing 75% of the ASX 200 by market, with 43% of companies' consensus EPS revised higher in FY18 compared to 34% revised lower."

"We would be buyers of weakness in Energy and Global Earners, embrace value over Bond Poxy Defensives and stay cautious on Domestic Cyclicals. We also focus on Gold, with the recent addition of EVN in our model portfolio - we see it playing a key role end-cycle role, with the question more around timing."

Street Talk

Perpetual ramps up succession; runs ruler over Pinnacle

Stockbroker levy in focus to top up rescue fund

Polygon on the block; Healthcare Australia offers due

with Reuters, Bloomberg, AAP

Comments? Questions? Let us know what you think of Before the Bell: timothy.moore@fairfaxmedia.com.au

urn:contentItem:60D0-DV81-DY19-C17P-00000-00ASX to edge up, Wall St pulls back2020-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:09ZLexisNexisASX to edge up, Wall St pulls backTimothy Moore

Australian shares appear set to open modestly higher, though as US head toward a lower close positive sentiment may prove difficult to maintain.

Australian shares appear poised to edge higher at the open, even as equities pull back in New York and Europe.

ASX futures were up 14 points or 0.2% to 5990 at 7am AEST. The currency slid 0.5%.

Shares closed lower in New York, though slightly off their session lows. The S&P 500 slipped 0.3% with six of its 11 industry groups declining.

As for the Dow, it slid 0.5% with losses paced by Boeing, Microsoft and Visa.

While US retail sales rebounded 7.5% in June, the data failed to offset concern about the virus spreading across the nation and as reopening decisions are reversed.

Retail gains in June and July are unlikely to be repeated, according to Pantheon Macroeconomics: "they'll start to reverse rapidly in August if enhanced unemployment benefits aren't extended after July 31??? and the strength of the control measure is misleading."

Most of the spending bounce is the result of unemployment benefits as well as one-time stimulus payments, Pantheon also said.

"If enhanced benefits are not extended by the end of July, they will expire, and household incomes will be exposed to the full collapse in payrolls.

"Our base case remains that this won't happen, and that Republicans in the Senate are too scared by recent polling to throw many millions of people into penury just three months before the election. As of right now, though, that's exactly what's scheduled to happen, and at least some prominent Republican voices, including former FOMC nominee Stephen Moore, are urging Senators not to extend the benefits."

Also denting sentiment was Netflix's quarterly report after New York's closing bell.

Shares in Netflix tumbled 10% after the company reported what OANDA's Edward Moya said were "disappointing earnings and anemic subscriber guidance.

"Netflix is struggling to produce new content and that will hurt subscriber growth. With new big movies not coming until second half of 2021, it is hard to get excited about their outlook over the next 12 months. Netflix and all streaming related companies, such as ROKU will selloff following this corporate update.

"The first of the mega-cap techs earnings report will likely see investor continue to scale-down their tech heavy bets," Mr Moya said. "Asian equities are not getting favours following Netflix's outlook and Trump's conditions for the next fiscal stimulus package."

Today's agenda

Local: BusinessNZ manufacturing PMI June

Overseas data: US June housing starts and building permits, University of Michigan consumer sentiment July

Market highlights

ASX futures up 14 points or 0.2% to 5990 at 7am AEST

From today's Financial Review

PM pushes for IR flex to ensure jobs recovery: The Morrison government is signalling it will extend industrial relations workplace changes, as the Victorian outbreak threatens a jobs recovery.

McFarlane warns red tape could choke off recovery: Westpac's new chairman, John McFarlane, is wary that regulations are making it 'genuinely difficult for banks to lend now'.

AMP Capital hit with poor returns in shopping mall fund: AMP Capital's $29 billion real estate arm, led by Carmel Hourigan, has been hit with poor returns in its flagship shopping mall fund.

Myths of the palace plot to sack Whitlam debunked: The release of the Kerr Palace letters this week, which promised to reveal evidence of interference from Buckingham Palace in the dismissal of Gough Whitlam, proved the very opposite, writes Anne Twomey.

United States

Retail sales in the US rose 7.5% last month after jumping 18.2% in May, which was the biggest gain since the government started tracking the series in 1992. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast retail sales advancing 5% in June.

Retail sales have rebounded as businesses resumed operations after being shuttered in mid-March in an effort to slow the spread of the respiratory illness. Retail sales in June were driven by an 8.2% increase in receipts at auto dealerships. Consumers stepped up spending at furniture, clothing, electronics and appliance, hobby, musical instrument and book stores. Receipts at restaurants and bars shot up 20.0%.

Economists expect consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, declined at as much as a 35% annualised rate in the April-June quarter. That could result in GDP falling at around a 31% pace in that period. The economy shrank at a 5% pace in the January-March quarter, the sharpest contraction since the 2007-2009 Great Recession.

"Activity snapped back in May and June, albeit to levels below those which prevailed prior to the pandemic," said Michael Feroli, chief US economist at JPMorgan in New York. "More recently, several high-frequency indicators suggest that May and June were the easy months, and that the resurgence of COVID-19 cases is leading to slower activity gains in July."

Separately, the Labor Department said 1.30 million people filed for state unemployment benefits during the week ending July 11, down 10,000 from the prior period. Economists had forecast 1.250 million claims last week.

Wedbush reiterates bullish view on big tech: The pandemic shift to working from home provides both defensive and offensive reasons why investors should own shares in the biggest US tech companies.

Morgan Stanley joins Wall Street gold rush on record profit: Fixed-income trading revenue almost tripled, driving a 73 per cent jump in total trading that surged past expectations.

Europe

European shares ended off session lows on Thursday ahead of a keenly awaited meeting to organise a European recovery fund, after weak earnings and a growing number of COVID-19 cases had earlier pushed stocks down from one-month highs.

European Central Bank chief Christine Lagarde kept policy steady, as expected, and said the bank expected a pending European Union stimulus scheme to favour grants over loans, as hoped by investors.

Leaders of the 27 EU states are due to meet on Friday to try to hammer out their differences over how the ???750 billion recovery fund will operate.

"We do not see an agreement being reached as the base case ahead of this EU summit," said strategists at ING. "We expect some progress towards a compromise being made, but some time for more negotiations is still required."

"This should allow a consolidation of the notion that the EU Recovery Fund will eventually come into existence - without having to be materially re-sized first."

The pan-European STOXX 600 closed down 0.7% after falling as much as 1% during the session. Germany's DAX and France's CAC 40 both cut session losses to end about 0.4% lower.

Italy's FTSE MIB turned positive, boosted by gains in Telecom Italia and Intesa Sanpaolo. Intesa is very confident of a positive outcome to its bid for smaller rival UBI Banca, a company executive said.

Asia

China stocks posted their biggest fall in more than five months on Thursday, as investors cooled down their buying spree on signs of policy tightening after the country's economic growth in the second quarter beat expectations.

The Shanghai Composite index closed down 4.5% at 3210.10, while the blue-chip CSI300 index was down 4.8%, their largest drops since February 3.

The tech-heavy start-up board ChiNext Composite index slumped 5.9%, also its worst session since February 3.

Investors are taking profit from the bull run in the last two weeks that has priced in a rebound in China's economy, analysts said. Foreign investors are also turning to sell Chinese stocks on worries of deteriorating Sino-US relations, they added.

China's GDP grew 3.2% in the second quarter, beating expectation, but domestic consumption and investment remained weak.

"Policy will remain supportive, but the pace of loosening may moderate given the strong credit expansion of the past months and the recent market surge," said Nathan Chow, economist at DBS Bank in Singapore.

At the close of trade in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index was down 510.89 points or 2% at 24,970.69. The Hang Seng China Enterprises index fell 2.47% to 10,133.92.

Currencies

Capital Economics on the outlook for the euro: "Failure by EU leaders to approve the Recovery Fund this weekend would probably weigh on the euro in the near term, but we still think that policymakers will eventually reach an agreement and provide another boost to the euro.

"Today's ECB meeting has given a bit of a lift to the euro and it has generally been a good month for the currency. It has risen by nearly 2% against the US dollar so far in July and that exchange rate is now well above its level at the start of the year."

Capital Economics' end-2020 forecast is $US1.20/???, which compares to a current level of about $US1.14/???.

Commodities

TD Securities argues that the outlook is for higher oil prices: "Following a sharp recovery, oil prices have struggled to firm further amid slowing energy demand growth, just as US shale production appears to stabilise and OPEC+ tapers its historic cuts. Notwithstanding, decomposing market expectations, we find that energy markets have already discounted easing supply-side support. And, we continue to expect significant deficits on the horizon nonetheless.

"The future of energy prices will be driven by the shale patch. It is quite possible that shale production has peaked for the foreseeable future ??? the cost of capital for production has risen, potentially permanently so. Expected capital expenditures are still declining at a record clip. With budgets under pressure, the share of exploration spending in total investment may hit historic lows, while unconventional projects have less scope for further cost reductions.

"This creates a set-up in which energy prices could potentially trade significantly higher. In a post-pandemic world, demand may well continue to recover while US supply growth could remain constrained. Nothing cures low prices like low prices. Such is the anatomy of a Great Rebalancing.

Australian sharemarket

Hopes a vaccine to end the COVID-19 pandemic may be just around the corner propped up the local travel sector on Thursday and gave new life to one of the most contrarian trades in the market: buying the recovery.

Brace for an earnings season to remember, warns 2020's top fundie: QVG portfolio manager Josh Clark believes the coming results will test the willingness of investors to back companies operating in a disclosure vacuum.

While the S&P/ASX 200 Index dropped 42 points, or 0.7 per cent, to 6010.9, travel exposed stocks closed the session higher and were among the market's best performers.

Street Talk  

Buy in bulk: PwC picks up Deloitte trio

Charter Hall in race for Qube's $2.5b Moorebank logistics park

KKR bankers up for Kinetic bus auction

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60K9-PD11-DY19-C1H8-00000-00ASX to open flat, Wall St mixed2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:09ZLexisNexisASX to open flat, Wall St mixedTimothy Moore

Australian shares are set to open little changed with US stocks mixed to start their week. NAB July business survey ahead.

Australian shares are poised for a muted open with trading mixed in New York.

ASX futures were down 3 points to 6067 at 7am AEST. The currency slipped.

Shares closed mixed in New York with the Dow up more than 358 points or 1.3 per cent. Twenty three of the Dow's 30 components were higher, paced by Boeing, Capterpillar and Dow Inc; Microsoft was the biggest loser.

The S&P 500 edged higher; energy paced six of the industry sectors higher. The Nasdaq ended lower as techs mostly lagged. Atlassian slid 2.9%. Amazon, Alphabet, Facebook and Netflix each slipped; Apple rose 1.5%, keeping the $US2 trillion market cap target in sight.

"Wall Street continues to see investors scale down their mega-cap tech bets and focus on beaten energy, industrial, materials, and consumer discretionary stocks," OANDA's Edward Moya said in a morning note.

"Tech's meteoric rise couldn't last forever, but by no means is it over," Mr Moya also said. "A tighter regulatory environment and higher taxes could be a drag for tech with a Biden presidency, but weakness should be limited to only a few percentage points."

Earnings season:  AFR profit season calendar and results: On today's schedule: Challenger (CGF), Coronado Global Resources (CRN), James Hardie Industries (JHX), SCA Property Group (SCP).

Today's agenda

Local: NAB business survey July, Weekly payrolls

Overseas data: Japan current account June; Euro zone ZEW expectations August; UK ILO unemployment rate June US PPI final July, NFIB small business optimism July

Market highlights

ASX futures were down 3 points to 6067 at 7am AEST

From today's Financial Review

JobKeeper becomes DividendKeeper: Retailers getting millions of dollars in JobKeeper program wage subsidies are posting higher profits and paying bigger dividends to their shareholders.

Huawei data centre built to spy on PNG: Major cyber security flaws were found in the Beijing-funded data centre in Port Moresby, where government files could be easily stolen without detection.

Chanticleer:  ASIC finally lets Brenner separate personal and business: Having protested her innocence against personal misconduct suggestions, the former AMP chairman's name has been cleared after two years living under a cloud.

Super funds forecast to tip $100b into private equity: They will increase their allocation to the asset class from 4.6 per cent to 7.5 per cent over the next five years, says Boston Consulting Group.

Chanticleer:  Future Fund's $30b crisis response: The Future Fund has increased its cash holdings by about $10 billion since March, and new CEO Raphael Arndt says the fund is positioned to take advantage.

United States

Yardeni on how to value US equities: "While the current P/E undoubtedly will revert to the mean eventually, that might not be a very useful insight if the mean has moved higher when adjusted for record-low bond yields. In other words, it could just as easily revert to a higher P/E as to a lower one, which would still be above the historical average.

"In a world of zero interest rates, maybe the new normal mean P/E is 30, twice what it was during the old normal. We don't have a model that says that 30 is the new normal. All we are saying is that the new normal mean P/E might be higher than the current reading of 22.1 rather than lower and closer to the old normal's 15.0 average."

LPL Financial on the disconnect between the S&P 500 and the US economy: "The next leg of the economic recovery may be tougher. Although we expect a COVID-19 vaccine, if not multiple vaccines, to clear human trials by year-end, it may take additional time to find a vaccine that's safe and effective.

"With the S&P 500 already having eclipsed the high end of our year-end fair-value target of 3300, and given a number of risks in addition to COVID-19, such as the upcoming US presidential election and escalating US-China tensions, the upside for stocks over the rest of the year may be limited. But we would say the same thing about bonds, which leads us to maintain our tactical overweight equities allocation."

Europe

European shares closed slightly higher on Monday as growth-sensitive cyclical stocks got a boost from improving economic data out of China.

With trading volumes dwindling as traders leave for summer holidays, the broader European STOXX 600 index held to tight ranges, ending the session 0.3% higher. The benchmark saw trading volume down to nearly 75% of its 30-day moving average.

Energy majors BP, Royal Dutch Shell and Total rose between 1.3% and 3% as crude oil prices rose.

Banking sector stocks rose 2.0%, leading sectoral gains, while the travel & leisure index, which has dealt a heavy blow in the wake of the health crisis, rose 0.9%.

Carnival Plc jumped 9.3% as it planned to resume AIDA Cruises sailing operations from German ports at the start of September.

However, equity analysts at JPMorgan Cazenove argued they do not a see a case for a sustained rally in the cyclical stocks.

"For Cyclicals and Value to work from here, one needs to see a continued acceleration in the PMIs. We think this is unlikely," JPMorgan's Mislav Matejka wrote to clients.

Technology stocks, which have outperformed this year in Europe, slid 1.5% on worries over the heightening US-China rift ahead of scheduled talks on August 15 to review the trade agreement signed in January.

Asia

Hong Kong shares ended lower on Monday, weighed down by rising tensions between Beijing and Washington.

At the close of trade, the Hang Seng index was down 154.19 points or 0.63% at 24,377.43. The Hang Seng China Enterprises index fell 0.72% to 9990.67.

At the close, the Shanghai Composite index was up 0.75% at 3,379.25, after earlier falling as much as 0.57%.

The blue-chip CSI300 index was up 0.36%, clawing back from a 1.31% fall. The CSI financial sector sub-index ended 1.34% higher, the consumer staples sector added 0.11%, the real estate index jumped 3.08% and the healthcare sub-index closed 0.62% lower.

The broader market gains came after data showed that China's factory deflation eased in July, driven by a rise in global oil prices and as industrial activity climbed back towards pre-coronavirus levels, adding to signs of economic recovery

Currencies

OANDA's Edward Moya on bitcoin: "After a wild start to the trading week, bitcoin and the other top cryptocurrencies are rising higher after Russia decided to avoid banning cryptocurrencies and as Facebook remains committed to creating a payments platform to run through all their projects.

"Bitcoin's latest rally was predominantly following the unprecedented stimulus trade that triggered the dollar's demise, but now the next move higher seems to be taking form on improving fundamentals for the crypto space. Bitcoin should continue to attract further institutional interest as big Tech breaks becomes a bigger part of daily transactional payments. Bitcoin seems poised to make a quick run towards the $US12,000 level and eventually the $US13,200 region."

Commodities

China, the world's biggest consumer of aluminium and zinc, launched options contracts for both on the Shanghai Futures Exchange on Monday, drawing lukewarm interest on the first day of trade.

The roll out follows the launch of copper options almost two years ago and comes after a recent rally in the base complex driven by a strong recovery in Chinese demand and concerns of supply disruption overseas.

Shanghai base metals fell across the board on Monday, however.

Malaysia's palm oil inventories fell to three-year lows in July as production declined due to labour shortages and heavy rains while exports rose amid easing coronavirus-related curbs, official data showed on Monday.

End-July stockpiles in the world's second-largest palm producer declined 10.55% from a month earlier to 1.7 million tonnes, while output fell 4.14% to 1.81 million tonnes, the Malaysian Palm Oil Board (MPOB) said

Australian sharemarket

The Australian sharemarket shot to a three-week high on Monday, driven by a stronger-than-expected US July labour force report and an extension of key economic support measures by President Donald Trump.

The S&P/ASX 200 Index advanced 105.4 points, or 1.8 per cent, to 6110.2, its highest level since July 21.

Street Talk  

Japan Post puts together Toll sale team, vendor DD next step

Jarden eyes off ally Credit Suisse's stake in EL&C Baillieu

Fintech Douugh prepares to lodge prospectus for backdoor listing

But many analysts believe stocks have room to rise. "Right now, it looks to us like the economy's going to be improving. They're ...
